title: Stigma for mental health problems in hiring

content.description: Several different employers were sent resumes of potential employees. The resumes were sent to the employers in pairs. Both candidates were equally qualified, but in each pair, one applicant described mental health problems as an explanation for the reason they left their previous job. The results showed that applicants reporting mental health problems had a 27% lower probability of getting an interview.
content.question: Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the results of this study?

choices.label: Employers overuse the availability heuristic in the hiring process.
There is cultural stigma around mental health problems that make employers less likely to hire those afflicted.
Ageism persists in the workplace and often leads to discriminatory hiring practices.
Employers tend to make decisions based on the central route to persuasion, and the information provided was more aligned to the peripheral route to persuasion.

content.answer: There is cultural stigma around mental health problems that make employers less likely to hire those afflicted.

skill.text: 1.B: Explain how cultural norms, expectations, and circumstances, as well as cognitive biases apply to behavior and mental processes.
